revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

{{stack begin}} {{Taxobox | image = Cystodermella cinnabarina.JPG | image_width = 235px | status = | regnum = [[Fungi]] | phylum = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Agaricaceae]] | genus = ''[[Cystodermella]]'' | species = '''''C. cinnabarina''''' | binomial = ''Cystodermella cinnabarina'' | binomial_authority = ([[Johannes Baptista von Albertini|Alb.]] & [[Lewis David de Schweinitz|Schwein.]]) [[Harri Harmaja|Harmaja]] | synonyms = ''Agaricus granulosus'' var. ''cinnabarinus''
''Agaricus terreyi''
''Armillaria cinnabarina''
''Cystoderma cinnabarinum''
''Cystoderma terreyi''
''Lepiota cinnabarina''
''Lepiota terreyi''{{cite web | title=''Cystodermella cinnabarina'' taxon record details at Index Fungorum | publisher=CAB International | url=http://www.indexfungorum.org/Names/NamesRecord.asp?RecordID=372397 | accessdate=December 13, 2009 }} }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Cystodermella cinnabarina'' | whichGills = emarginate | whichGills2 = adnate | capShape = convex | capShape2 = flat | hymeniumType = gills | stipeCharacter = ring | ecologicalType = saprotrophic | sporePrintColor = white | howEdible = caution }} {{stack end}} '''''Cystodermella cinnabarina''''' is a [[Basidiomycota|basidiomycete]] [[fungus]] of the genus ''[[Cystodermella]]''. Its [[Sporocarp (fungi)|fruiting body]] is a small [[agaric]] bearing a distinctive reddish-coloured grainy [[pileus (mycology)|cap]]. It occurs in [[coniferous forest|coniferous]] and [[deciduous forest]]s throughout the world. Prior to 2002, this species belonged to genus ''[[Cystoderma]]'', subsection Cinnabarina, under the name '''''Cystoderma cinnabarinum''''' which is still sometimes applied. Another often used synonym is '''''Cystoderma terreyi'''''. ==Taxonomy== The species was first described as ''Agaricus granulosus'' var. ''cinnabarinus'' by German botanist [[Johannes Baptista von Albertini]] and the American [[Lewis David de Schweinitz]] in 1805.{{cite book |title=Conspectus fungorum in Lusatiae Superioris agro Niskiensi crescentium|vauthors=Albertini JB, von Schweinitz LD |year=1805 |publisher=Lipsiae, Sumtibus Kummerianis |location= |page=147 |url=https://archive.org/stream/conspectusfungor00albe#page/146/mode/2up |accessdate=2009-12-17 |language=Latin}} The species has also been known variously as ''Agaricus terreyi'' ([[Miles Joseph Berkeley|Berkeley]] and [[Christopher Edmund Broome|Broome]], 1870),{{cite journal |vauthors=Berkeley MJ, Broome CE |year=1870 |title=Notices of British fungi (1182–1262) |journal=Annals and Magazine of Natural History |volume=6 |series=IV |pages=461–69}} ''Armillaria cinnabarina'' ([[Calvin Henry Kauffman|Kauffman]], 1922),{{cite journal |author=Kauffmann CH. |year=1922 |title=The genus ''Armillaria'' in the United States and its relationships |journal=Papers of the Michigan Academy of Sciences |volume=2 |issue= |pages=53–67}} ''Lepiota cinnabarina'' ([[Petter Karsten|Karsten]], 1914),{{cite book |title=Die Blätterpilze |author= Karsten P. |year=1914 |publisher=T. O. Weigel |location=Leipzig |page=327|url=http://caliban.mpiz-koeln.mpg.de/ricken/tafeln_screen/IMG_2720.jpg |accessdate=2009-12-17|language=German}} and ''Cystoderma terreyi'' ([[Harri Harmaja|Harmaja]], 1978).{{cite journal |author=Harmaja H. |year=1978 |title=New species and combinations in the pale-spored Agaricales |journal=Karstenia |volume=18 |pages=29–30}} == Description == [[File:Cystodermella cinnabarina 456.jpg|thumb|left|View of the cap, gills, and stem]] The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is hemispherical in shape at first, becoming convex and finally flat with maturity, and reaching a diameter of up to {{convert|8|cm|in|1|abbr=on}}. The cap [[pileipellis|cuticle]] is [[cinnabar]], brick-red or rusty orange and densely covered with fine granules. The [[Trama (mycology)|flesh]] is white to pallid, with a mild fungoid taste and barely discernible smell. The [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] are white to cream, dense and emarginate or adnate. A finely cottony [[partial veil]] covers the gills in immature specimens, tearing away to leave behind a delicate [[Annulus (mycology)|ring]]. The [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] is white above the ring, and scaly below, with dark orange squamules. The stem is up to {{convert|6|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} tall and {{convert|1.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} in diameter, sometimes bulbous in the base and hollow. === Microscopic characteristics === The [[basidiospore]]s are oval, [[hyaline]], and [[Amyloid (mycology)|non-amyloid]], with dimensions of 3.5–5 by 2.5–3.5 [[micrometre|µm]]. The [[spore print]] is white.{{cite book | author=Ts. Hinkova | year=1986 | title=Нашите Гъби (Our Mushrooms) | page=95 | publisher=Zemizdat (Bulgaria) }}{{cite journal | author=Sesli E. | year=2005 | title=''Cystoderma cinnabarinum'' (Alb. & Schwein.) Fayod, a New Turkish Mycota Record |journal=Turkish Journal of Botany | issue=6 | volume=29 | pages=463–466 | issn= }} The [[basidia]] ([[spore]]-producing cells) are club-shaped, and 17–24 by 4–5 µm. ''C. cinnabarina'' always has cells called cheilocystidia—[[cystidia]] that are present on the edges of gills, which in this species are spear-shaped. This microscopic feature may be used to help distinguish it from the similar-coloured ''[[Cystodermella adnatifolia|C. adnatifolia]]''{{cite journal |author=Saar I. |year=2003 |title=The genera ''Cystoderma'' and ''Cystodermella'' (Tricholomataceae) in temperate Eurasia|journal=Mycotaxon|volume=86 |issue= |pages=455–73}} and ''[[Cystodermella granulosa|C. granulosa]]'', which also bear non-amyloid spores, but lack cystidia. Species of ''[[Cystoderma]]'' (including orange-capped species such as ''[[Cystoderma amianthinum]]'') have amyloid spores, in comparison to non-amyloid spores in ''C. cinnabarina'' and species of ''[[Cystodermella]]'' in general. This is determined by staining tissue with chemicals in the [[amyloid reaction]]—all ''[[Cystodermella]]'' species show a negative reaction (spores remain colourless).{{cite journal |vauthors=Saar I, Põldmaa K, Kõljalg U |year=2009 |title=The phylogeny and taxonomy of genera ''Cystoderma'' and ''Cystodermella'' (Agaricales) based on nuclear ITS and LSU sequences|journal=Mycological Progress|volume=8 |issue= |pages=59–73 |doi=10.1007/s11557-008-0578-9}} ==Habitat and distribution== ''Cystodermella cinnabarina'' is found fruiting in [[coniferous]] and [[deciduous]] forests,{{cite web | title=''Cystoderma cinnabarinum'' at Mushroom Expert | publisher=Kuo M | url=http://www.mushroomexpert.com/cystoderma_cinnabarinum.html | accessdate=December 13, 2009 }} on ground among moss, grass and [[Plant litter|litter]]. Being a [[saprotroph]]ic fungus, it decays dead organic matter. It has been recorded under [[Pinus|pine]] (''[[Pinus nigra]]'', ''[[Pinus pinea]]''), [[Quercus|oak]], [[Picea|spruce]] (''[[Picea orientalis]]''), [[Abies|fir]] (''[[Abies cephalonica]]'') and [[chestnut]] (''[[Castanea sativa]]'') in [[Greece]] and [[Turkey]].{{cite journal | author=Dimou D. M. | author2=Zervakis G. I. | author3=Polemis E. | year=2008 | title=Mycodiversity studies in selected ecosystems of Greece:IV. Macrofungi from ''Abies cephalonica'' forests and other intermixed tree species (Oxya Mt., central Greece) |journal=Mycotaxon | volume=104 | pages=39–42 | issn= }} Fruiting bodies appear solitary or in small groups, during the summer and autumn. It is widely distributed around the world on continents including Asia, Africa, Europe and North America, though in many places it is uncommon.{{cite web|title=''Cystoderma cinnabarinum'' at Rogers Mushrooms |publisher=Rogers Plants Ltd. |url=http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5891.asp |accessdate=December 13, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706060647/http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5891.asp |archivedate=July 6, 2008 }} The preliminary [[Regional Red List|red data list]] of threatened British fungi lists ''Cystodermella cinnabarinum'' under the [[IUCN]] "[[Near Threatened]]" status.{{cite web | title=The Red Data List of Threatened British Fungi | publisher=British Mycological Society | url=http://www.britmycolsoc.org.uk/files/RDL_of_Threatened_British_Fungi_Version_1.0.pdf | accessdate=December 13, 2009 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==Edibility== ''Cystodermella cinnabarina'' has been variously described as inedible, though harmless,{{cite web|title=''Cystoderma cinnabarinum'' at Fungipedia.es |publisher=Javier Perez Calvo |url=http://www.fungipedia.es/clasificacion-orden/basidiomycota/36-tricholomatales/244-cystoderma-cinnabarinum.html |language=Spanish |accessdate=December 13, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091219031705/http://fungipedia.es/clasificacion-orden/basidiomycota/36-tricholomatales/244-cystoderma-cinnabarinum.html |archivedate=December 19, 2009 }} and even edible{{cite book|author=Boa E. R.|year=2006|title="Champignons Comestibles Sauvages" (Edible Wild Mushrooms)|page=144|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|isbn=92-5-205157-0|language=French}} regionally, for example, in [[Hong Kong]]. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q3915588}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cystodermella Cinnabarina}} [[Category:Agaricaceae]] [[Category:Fungi of Asia]] [[Category:Fungi of Africa]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Inedible fungi]] [[Category:Edible fungi]]
